text:
Andrew Ng: What advice would you have for 
someone wanting to break into Machine Learning?

Chris Manning: It's a great time to break in, I 
think theres no doubt at all that we're still

in the early stages of seeing the impact of this 
new approach where effectively software computer

science is being reinvented. So just lots of 
opportunities for more automation making more

use of interpretation of human language material 
for me, or in other areas like vision and robotics.

So you want to get some kind of good foundation, 
right? So knowing some of the core technical

methods of machine learning, understanding ideas 
and how to build models and data, diagnose errors, all of

these core things. Beyond that, I think it's also 
useful to learn something about human language and

the nature of the problems that involves. 
I mean even though people aren't directly

going to be encoding rules of human language into 
their computing system, a sensitivity to sort of

what kind of things happen in language and what 
to look out, and what you might want to model,
um that's still a useful skill to have.
